content.description: Highly pocketed face sport route, which climbs easier than it appears.
content.protection: Seven bolts; five painted red Metolius hangers on route and two older SMCs for belay/rap anchor.
content.location: In between Run-It-Out on its left and Spaghetti Western on its right.

content.description: Starts below and south of a significant boulder pile, beginning with a steep, wide crack. About a quarter of the way up, we crossed a face into another parallel, right-arching crack. Lay right on corner of this left crack system, while using numerous face pockets to the two bolt belay/rap anchor.
content.protection: Standard Supes rack; cams, nuts and tricams.
content.location: Right (west) of the other listed Unknown three bolt sport route ('99 Rock Climbing Arizona).

content.description: The book has this listed as 5.10c but that is not the case.  While the bolt spacing may seem spacious, the moves between clips are not that difficult.  Although, a fall from the last bolt going to the top would be disastrous, the climbing is 5.4.  Going from bolt one to two is the probable crux.  A good warmup for Christian Arete or Enga's First.
content.location: This climb is left of the route Unknown, 5.7.  All three bolts can be easily seen from the base.

content.description: A steep, pocketed face with the crux coming near the top.  Save your energy for the moves between the final two bolts or prepare for some airtime.
content.protection: 5 bolts.  Two rap bolts at top.
content.location: This climb is to the right of The Last Fool A-Hammerin' and to the left of Unknown, 5.10-.

content.description: Crux is the lower face near the only bolt/SMC hanger, after that it gets easier in the haphazard crack system. High decking potential if you don't make it to the first sketchy placements.
content.protection: Three bolts; one low on route and two for belay/rap anchor. Small cams and/or nuts.
content.location: Right of the Unknown 5.7 crack (up and around corner) and left of the Unknown five bolt sport route.

content.description: Face climb crimps and edges above right-angling groove past first clip and bulge. Continue past two horizontal seams and use deeper pockets to clip bolt two and three.
content.protection: Five bolts; three on route and two for anchor. Small cam or tricam for horizontal seam between clip one and two.
content.location: Left of Electric Raguland and right of an unknown, five bolt sport route.

content.description: On the right (north) side of east-facing wall there are some large boulders. Above them, you can climb a short, low-angle seam to large angled ledge. Climb crux face to first clip. We then moved right to place a few cams in a horizontal crack, veered left and up highly pocketed face past two more bolts.
content.protection: Five bolts total. Three on route and shared two bolt anchor at top.
content.location: Northwest of The Cemetery (backside BCW). Left of The Last Fool A-Hammerin' just around the NE corner of Myth Wall.

content.description: Distinctive route that climbs pocketed face to the right of rounded arete passing two bolts. Transitions left onto easy slab where some pro can be placed to somewhat protect the steep moves to the third bolt. This upper pocketed face through the third and fourth clips is the crux.
content.protection: Six bolts; four on route and two for belay/rap.
content.location: Next route to the right of Fluff Boys in Heat. Starts below and east of the massive Sundeck Boulder.

content.description: We top-roped this route and it was great, a lead would be stout, pumpy and would definitely feel even more difficult.  Clip two bolts off some crimps and aim for the finger crack.  Some big reaches will place you even further away from the security of the bolts and eventually to a wondrous, horizontal jam and protection.  Clip one more bolt and punch-it to the top, eases off after pulling past third bolt.
content.protection: 3 bolts, small and medium cams for the lead. Two old, rusty bolts at top.
content.location: This route is right of the climb named Never Named It, 5.8.  The lower two bolts are easily seen from base.

content.description: Traversing onto the white slab midway up and mantling the juggy roof above is probably the crux. Lower and upper sections are not as technical, but demand creative pro placements or none at all.
content.protection: Standard Supes rack; cams, nuts and tricams with two bolts/SMC hangers at the top.
content.location: Around the corner and right of Christian Arete. This is the first route on the left side of Myth Wall's main area (Sundeck Boulder).

content.description: Begins in steep, shallow dihedral that's punctuated with a good hand crack on the middle right. This lower shallow chute seemed like the crux as the upper left-angling crack and steeper bolted face has many giant pockets and knobs and eventually more crack options.
content.protection: Six bolts; four on route and two for belay/rap anchor. Lower crux chute can be protected with a medium cam in hand crack.
content.location: I think this is the route left of Christian Arete. It's listed in '99 Rock Climbing Arizona as a trad route with no bolts, but seems to have been bolted with newer hardware (not SMC hangers). It starts below the large, green lichen-covered slab that is in the approximate middle of the northwest face.

content.description: Belay at top of large boulder pile. Climb easy slab up to bolt, then up steeper, thinner face past another bolt to gain a good ledge. Continue up overhanging face using pockets past another third clip to anchor. The top isn't runout anymore because of an added lower two bolt anchor, but there's ledge fall potential elsewhere on the route.
content.protection: Five bolts; three on route and two for belay/rap anchor (shared with Enga's First).
content.location: Right-side of steep arete to the right of Enga's First face.

content.description: A mainly northwest-facing crag nestled within a convoluted hodgepodge of steep walls, haphazard pinnacles, meandering grooves and perched boulders. None of the routes are more than eighty-five feet high, but about eighty-five percent of them are rated greater than 5.10 in difficulty. Many are mixed sport that can be augmented with pro between clips. For this area, only three of the published routes in '99 Rock Climbing Arizona are pure trad.
